text:
(Brady: This idea of an Erdős 
number, this came)
(up after he passed away did it?)

No, before. 
- (He knew about it then?)

Yeah, yeah, he even kind of promoted.
He said, on a
fundamental problem in mathematics, a
kind of a joke you see? You connect two
people if they have a joint paper and
this is like constructing a graph where
the points are the people that you put
an edge if they have a joint paper. He
cared a lot about collaboration and
joint papers and joint work and so he
had a lot of co-authors. He had a theory,
not a real theory, that if he had
more living co-authors than dead
co-authors he'd be okay, you see? Somehow
as soon as the number of dead ones
started, you know, overwhelming the living
ones then he knows his time is coming too.
Erdős had another variation; if
you have n papers with him your Erdős
number should be 1 over n, it's
close to zero. So mines 1 over 27 or 28,
something like that, but there are people
have about 60 papers so- But, you know, it
isn't always just a number; Andrew Wiles
doesn't have that many papers, he's still
pretty well known. In
mathematics there are more - I think it's
probably true in a lot of fields but I
know about the math - people publish under
pseudonyms, ok? So here's an Erdős
number story of a pseudonym: so there was
a paper they were working, Erdős
and my wife Fan Chung, and some others,
Kleitman at MIT; and there was a five

author paper - it was a 
small result wasn't a
big thing. So we thought, why not take the
initials of the authors and make a name?
Turns out G. Peck, Gregory Peck, perfect.
Okay, G Peck, I was going to G Peck. Then
right at the end
another mathematician, Doug West,
contributed, made it simpler better okay.
Well, G.W. Peck, ok, G.W. Peck, why not?
Okay, so we published under G.W. Peck,
good, turns out that that had an
interesting concept and people kind of

picked up on the concept,
on partial ordered
sets called posets, and there were
Peck posets. And in particular

Kleitman, who's a professor, 
Dan Kleitman at MIT,
liked the name so much he started
publishing a few small papers under the

name G.W. Peck, MIT. 
Well, the Mathematical
Reviews sent letters to MIT, to

G.W. Peck, said we've noticed 
you've published
in this area, would you like to review
for us? And Peck said, sure. So Peck
started reviewing papers, and he reviewed
one of Kleitman's papers which is a
little incestuous. P was, again, George
Purdy at Cincinnati, I'm the G. C was
Chung, Fan Chung, K was Kleitman, E was
Erdős - it's good to have a vowel. Well
it turns out that Doug West never had a
paper with Erdős but it was only this.
And Jerry Griggs, who was another
mathematician, had a paper with Doug West
but he never had a paper with Erdős
so his Erdős number is 1 plus i, the i
is the imaginary. And in the complex
plane that's 1 plus i, that's closer
than distance 2, so it's an Erdős

number - kind of an imaginary
because it's
an imaginary- Of course in this paper G.W.
Peck thanks all of us for proving the
theorems, writing the paper, and so there
there are a number of papers like this
that you'd never know unless you know-
you know, like A. Nilli. A. Nilli is the
daughter of Noga Alon and she's

published like, I don't know,
a dozen papers. She
could probably get a pretty good job
someplace. That's just- that's a little
throwaway result you put it in, A. Nilli.
So yeah, G.W. Peck. So they had a a
reunion, Kleitman retired, they had a

talk by G.W. Peck; I was supposed 
to come but
I couldn't come, I think Doug West gave a
whole history. Turns that G.W. Peck was a
real person; George Washington Peck was a

politician in Wisconsin. 
And he has a whole

history and you can find out. 
So it turns out

it was a real person, that's- you never
know.
There is just a small postscript to
this story; a number of years later Doug
West did write a paper with Erdős using
their real names, taking his Erdős number
to 1. And for Jerry Griggs that meant
his Erdős number became 2, sort of

further away from Erdős in some respects
I guess.
Thank you to everyone who is
supporting Numberphile on Patreon,
especially these people. And also if
you'd like to get this new Numberphile
poster check out the links on the screen
and in the video description. The poster's
by artist Pete McPartlan and full of all
sorts of little details and gems from
Numberphile.
